doc.name: launch
doc.summary: Starts up an application, optionally opening a document in the application.

description.overview: Use the launch command to start an application for the user to use.

parameter.name: documentPath
parameter.description: The location and name of a file to open with the specified application. If no path is specified, the launch command assumes that the file is in the defaultFolder.

parameter.name: applicationPath
parameter.description: The location and name of the application to start up. If no path is specified, the launch command assumes that the application is in the defaultFolder.

description.comments:
When the launch command executes, the application being launched comes to the foreground. When the user quits, LiveCode comes to the foreground.
On Mac OS systems, if the application is already running, the launch command does nothing, and "Process is already open." is placed in the result function. On Windows and Linux, an additional instance of the application will start.
If no documentPath is specified, the following two statements are equivalent:
launch application
open process application for neither
On OS X systems, you can use the launch command to start up an application, but not a Unix process. To work with a Unix process, use the shell function instead.
On Windows systems, you can also start up an application by using the shell function with the Windows "start" command:
get shell("start MyProgram.exe")
